responsibleParty.investigatorTitle: Director of the Schizophrenia Clinical and Research Program

collaborators.name: National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study aims to examine factors potentially contributing to differences in blood folate, homocysteine or B12 levels between schizophrenia patients, to test the hypothesis that low folate is associated with negative symptoms, and to examine the efficacy of folate supplementation for reducing negative symptoms.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
This study is a three-month, placebo-controlled trial of folate 2mg/d in 50 schizophrenia patients who score at least a 3 (moderate or greater severity) on at least one of the SANS global assessment subscales, with the exception of the attention global assessment subscale. The specific aims of this study are:

* To examine factors potentially contributing to differences in blood folate, homocysteine or B12 levels between patients at baseline, including dietary intake and cigarette smoking.
* To test the hypothesis that low folate is associated with negative symptoms by examining correlations between red blood cell folate concentrations and clinical ratings of negative symptoms and by comparing folate concentrations in deficit syndrome versus non-deficit syndrome patients. We will also control for dietary intake cigarettes smoking, gender, and age.
* To examine the efficacy of folate supplementation for reducing negative symptoms

armGroups.label: Folate
armGroups.description: Participants will receive a 2 mg/ day dose of folate, for 12 weeks

armGroups.label: Placebo
armGroups.description: Participants will receive a 2 mg/ day dose of placebo, for 12 weeks

interventions.name: Folate
interventions.description: Folic acid taken as 2, 1mg capsule daily for 12 weeks

interventions.name: Placebo
interventions.description: Placebo taken as 2, 1mg capsule daily for 12 weeks

primaryOutcomes.measure: Correlation Between Baseline Blood Folate and Smoking Status
primaryOutcomes.description: Baseline blood folate lab levels are reported by smoking status.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Correlation Between Baseline Blood Folate and MTHFR Genotype
primaryOutcomes.description: Baseline blood folate lab levels are reported by MTHFR genotype.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Correlation Between Baseline Blood Folate Levels and Dietary Intake
primaryOutcomes.description: Baseline blood folate lab levels and dietary intake levels are reported.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Efficacy of Folate Supplementation for Reducing Negative Symptoms as Measured by the SANS Modified Total
primaryOutcomes.description: The change from baseline to week 12 on the scale for the assessment of negative symptoms (SANS) modified total score. Total SANS scores range from 0-100. The SANS is comprised of 5 sub-scales: Affective Flattening or Blunting (score range 0-35), Alogia (score range 0-20), Avolition-Apathy (score range 0-15), Anhedonia-Asociality (score range 0-20), and Attention (0-10). For each sub-scale, the higher the score the more prominent the negative symptoms were. The total score was computed by adding all the sub-scale total scores. To compute change in scores, baseline scores were subtracted from week 12 scores, resulting in a change score. Lower values signify greater improvement (i.e. week 12 score was lower than baseline score). The SANS modified total score is the SANS total score minus the Attention subscale.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Schizophrenia, any subtype
2. Ages 18-68
3. Male or female
4. A score at least a 3 (moderate or greater severity) on at least one of the SANS global assessment subscales, with the exception of the attention global assessment subscale
5. Stable antipsychotic dose for \> 6 weeks
6. Capable of providing informed consent

Exclusion Criteria:

1. Unstable medical illness
2. Substance abuse
3. Megaloblastic anemia
4. Non-english speaking

references.citation: Hill M, Shannahan K, Jasinski S, Macklin EA, Raeke L, Roffman JL, Goff DC. Folate supplementation in schizophrenia: a possible role for MTHFR genotype. Schizophr Res. 2011 Apr;127(1-3):41-5. doi: 10.1016/j.schres.2010.12.006. Epub 2011 Feb 21.

participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Forty six participants were enrolled; 38 completed screening and 32 received study drug.

outcomeMeasures.title: Correlation Between Baseline Blood Folate and Smoking Status
outcomeMeasures.description: Baseline blood folate lab levels are reported by smoking status.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: 1 past smoker and 1 never smoker are missing RBC folate values. For the present analysis, as opposed to a comparison of treatment groups, folate levels are compared across smoking status.

groups.title: Current Smoker

outcomeMeasures.title: Correlation Between Baseline Blood Folate and MTHFR Genotype
outcomeMeasures.description: Baseline blood folate lab levels are reported by MTHFR genotype.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: One participant with CC genotype is missing RBC folate value. For the present analysis, as opposed to a comparison of treatment groups, folate levels are compared across MTHFR genotype.

groups.title: CC Genotype
groups.description: Study participants with MTHFR genotype CC

groups.title: T- Genotype
groups.description: Participants with MTHFR genotype T (T allele carrier)

outcomeMeasures.title: Correlation Between Baseline Blood Folate Levels and Dietary Intake
outcomeMeasures.description: Baseline blood folate lab levels and dietary intake levels are reported.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All study participants at baseline. For the present analysis, as opposed to a comparison of treatment groups, folate levels are described for all participants at baseline.

outcomeMeasures.title: Efficacy of Folate Supplementation for Reducing Negative Symptoms as Measured by the SANS Modified Total
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to week 12 on the scale for the assessment of negative symptoms (SANS) modified total score. Total SANS scores range from 0-100. The SANS is comprised of 5 sub-scales: Affective Flattening or Blunting (score range 0-35), Alogia (score range 0-20), Avolition-Apathy (score range 0-15), Anhedonia-Asociality (score range 0-20), and Attention (0-10). For each sub-scale, the higher the score the more prominent the negative symptoms were. The total score was computed by adding all the sub-scale total scores. To compute change in scores, baseline scores were subtracted from week 12 scores, resulting in a change score. Lower values signify greater improvement (i.e. week 12 score was lower than baseline score). The SANS modified total score is the SANS total score minus the Attention subscale.
